newsitem.title: UK: UK retail, farming groups welcome food agency plan.
newsitem.headline: UK retail, farming groups welcome food agency plan.

text.p: Groups representing British farmers and retailers have welcomed proposals for a new food standards agency contained in a report sought by new British Prime Minister Tony Blair that was published on Thursday.
The British Retail Consortium said in a statement it looked forward to the better coordination of those areas of government with responsibility for food safety.
It supported the report's proposal that the new agency should be based in London, so as to be in close contact with the ministry of agriculture and the department of health.
The National Farmers Union said the report represented a welcome basis for future discussion and developments.

"The NFU has, for some time, advocated the need for independence on food safety issues, and for greater transparency and openness in food production systems," NFU president Sir David Naish said in statement.
A new agency would take on responsibility for the safety of British food from the farm ministry under proposals in the report, which was written by professor Philip James.
"I and my colleagues look forward to taking these issues forward with the government and professor Jones," Naish said.
